Dr. Robert Johnson is a professor and interim chair of pediatrics at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, New Jersey Medical School.
And he treats HIV-positive teenagers in New Jersey.
He joins us now from his office in Newark.
And it's nice to have you on the program today.
Good afternoon.
And what do you perceive as the reasons people, particularly young people, get infected with HIV these days?
Well, most of it is just because young people are having sex without any form of protection.
And we have a fairly large number of young people in our program who are HIV-infected, all of them have had sex with someone who's HIV-infected themselves, and then they acquire the infection.
One of the things that was a perception that we had years ago was that it had a lot to do with how much sex you had.
It's really much more who you have sex with.
Because if you have a lot of unprotected sex with people who are not HIV-infected, you'll never get HIV.
But if you have sex with a very few people who are HIV-infected, you will get HIV.
Now, among teens, that usually means sex with an older person, sex with an adult since there's more HIV in the adult population than in the teen population.
But that's what it amounts to.
There's almost no transmission from intravenous drug use among teenage populations.
It's all sexual activity.
We were just discussing the stigma of even getting tested with a caller.
Does that - play into a factor as well?
You know, it's - and I've heard that from around country.
It really depends upon where you are.
In Newark, we've made a concerted effort over the last 15 years to test as many teenagers as possible.
And so, throughout New Jersey, we pretty much normalize testing and so whenever you go and get a physical examination as a youth, usually, you get HIV-tested as well.
And at least the young people we see in Newark have that expectation that when they go in for an STD or STI test, they'll be also HIV-tested.
So, we don't have that much difficulty with stigma.
In our general adolescent clinics, we routinely ask young people if they're sexually active.
We ask them whether they're sexually active with people of the same sex as they or the opposite sex.
And we do complete STI testing as well as HIV testing.
And that's sort of an expectation.
And Brenda, I assume that varies community-community, state to state.
It does vary.

But the CDC has recommended that states put in place routine testing program so that anytime you go, say to an emergency room, the person has to say, I don't want to be tested, or they will be tested.
And that's the way it works in New Jersey.
I'm not sure how many states have done that.
It's just a recommendation, however.
In New York and New Jersey - those are two states I'm most familiar with - there are moves to that.
In Jersey, the commissioner of health has recommended that.
And you know, it varies by hospital or by practice whether it's doing - done.
I doubt that most physicians or health centers are doing it, but at least they are discussing it.
I also chair the governor's council on HIV and AIDS, and we recommended that throughout the state as well.

One of the reasons it's really important is that most people who are found to be HIV-infected have had a recent visit to a health care provider in the past, the past in which they probably were HIV-infected.
And they didn't have a test.
And so - and we know that it's really important to learn about your HIV status as early as possible.
And therefore, it's important that the medical community test everybody.
And that's testing without any consideration of relative risk or anything like that.
But everyone should be tested between 13 and 65.
